northern Saskatchewan remain on alert today as a forest fire continues to burn at the northern edge of town.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Many spent an uneasy night at home after being evacuated briefly yesterday when the blaze roared right into the community.</p><p>-BODY- Two trailers and a small building were destroyed or damaged, while eight houses just outside La Ronge went up in flames.</p><p>One of them belonged to a water bomber pilot who was out fighting the blaze.</p><p>About 15-hundred residents who fled their homes -- more than half the population -- were allowed to return about 10:30 p.m. when winds died down and the danger had passed.</p><p>A number of them stayed at the local arena where cots and food were supplied.</p><p>No one was injured.</p><p>The town administrator says volunteer firefighters patrolled all night, ready to run door-to-door and give the alert if winds picked up and sparked a new blaze.</p><p>John Wade also says the weather is cooler today and the wind is calm, which lessens the chance of the flames endangering La Ronge again.</p><p>The fire began southwest of the centre around noon yesterday.</p><p>Strong winds pushed it northeast and by 1:00 p.m., Mounties were running from house-to-house, asking people to leave. (BN, CP) --- KRT-LGA</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:51M5-VXR1-DYTJ-117G-00000-00Forest fire leaves dozens dead, many in bus crash: Israeli rescue service2010-12-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSForest fire leaves dozens dead, many in bus crash: Israeli rescue serviceDANIELLA CHESLOWAP

JERUSALEM _ A bus evacuating people from a massive forest fire Thursday in northern Israel went up in flames, killing dozens of guards who were helping to rescue inmates from a prison, officials said.

Fire officials said the blaze, which torched some 800 acres (325 hectares) and was one of the deadliest accidents in the country's history, remained out of control as nightfall arrived.

''This is a disaster of unprecedented proportions,'' Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said. He said the government was using all means at its disposal to contain the blaze.

The fire in the northern Carmel region broke out around midday, and within hours, authorities were clearing the area of hundreds of residents, as well as Palestinian inmates from a prison.

During the evacuation, a bus from the prison went up in flames. TV footage showed the charred skeleton of the bus, with dozens of bodies lying on the ground.

Yoram Levy, a spokesman for the national fire service, said some 40 people were killed as a result of the fire, most of them from the bus accident. He said officials suspected the fire erupted after people were burning garbage.

In a statement, Israel's prison service said the bus was carrying guards ''on their way to help in the rescue activities'' at the Damun prison.

Eli Bin, a spokesman for the Mada rescue service, said just three people survived the bus crash, and all suffered severe burns.

Israel has experienced an exceptionally hot summer and has had little rain this autumn, allowing the blaze to quickly spread.

''There is a fire burning, and we are not in control of these areas,'' said Yona Yahav, mayor of the northern city of Haifa. ''It's a sad day for the country.''

(CP) - Some 400 residents returned to their homes Friday after a fire that raced through a forest three kilometres from this Northern Ontario city was brought under control.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Firefighters had tamed most of the flames by Friday morning, but Timmins fire Chief Lester Cudmore said a state of emergency would remain in effect until the burned area had been completely surrounded.</p><p>"When you're talking about a bush fire, it can flare up even when it looks like it's out.''</p><p>No serious injuries were reported and the flames failed to reach any buildings.</p><p>The evacuation of two trailer parks in Mountjoy and Ogden townships was ordered soon after fire broke out west of the city late Thursday afternoon.</p><p>"It was like a big mushroom cloud and it was crowning - jumping from treetop to treetop - so you could almost see the flames from town,'' said Ben Legouffe, spokesman for Ontario's Natural Resources Ministry.</p><p>Mayor Vic Power declared a state of emergency about two hours later.</p><p>The fire, burning along a 200-hectare front and whipped up by high winds, jumped the 120-metre-wide Mattagami River and a highway.</p><p>For a while late Thursday, it looked like flames might engulf the city, Cudmore said.</p><p>"We could've had a major disaster on our hands.''</p><p>Three water bombers were brought in while eight crews from local fire departments and the Resources Ministry worked on the ground.</p><p>Fire crews couldn't venture into the bush Thursday because they might have been trapped by winds that quicky spread the fire from tree to tree.</p><p>The smoke was so thick that firefighters regularly had to be pulled off the line because they couldn't breathe.</p><p>At one point, the fire raced along the fence surrounding the Malette sawmill. But as firefighters soaked a $7-million inventory of lumber, the blaze veered away.</p><p>The forest fire was the first of the season for the area but Legouffe said they don't usually burn so close to the city.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:58C9-WRH1-JBVR-30V3-00000-00Emergency centre set up in New Brunswick town due to forest fire2013-05-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisWEATHER,NATIONAL,ATLANTICEmergency centre set up in New Brunswick town due to forest fireNew Brunswick town sets up emergency centreThe Canadian Press

KEDGWICK, N.B. - A reception centre has been set up in a community hall in a village in northwestern New Brunswick in case a forest fire forces people to flee their homes.

However, a spokesman for the provincial Department of Natural Resources says the fire has "subsided substantially" Tuesday night and there were no evacuations in Kedgwick, about 300 kilometres north of Fredericton.

A spokeswoman for the RCMP said earlier that some residents were being asked to evacuate because the fire was drawing dangerously close to the community.

Natural Resources official Charles Beaulieu said a meeting was held with residents Tuesday night to bring them up to speed on the situation and they returned to their homes.

Beaulieu says the fire covers about 75 hectares.

He says bulldozers planned to work around the community overnight and crews would be back working the fire in the morning.

Department spokeswoman Ann Bull said a fire in the Colpitts Settlement area, about 40 kilometres west of Moncton, had spread over a 500-hectare area and had destroyed at least two homes.

Tyson Lewis, the assistant deputy chief of the Moncton Fire Department, says some people living on Middlesex Road, near Colpitts Settlement, and along the Sanitorium Road, were asked to leave their homes.

He estimated eight fire departments were involved in fighting the blaze in southeastern New Brunswick.

The department says water bombers and helicopters were also dispatched to assist in fighting both fires.

Beaulieu says conditions are extremely dry and that the entire province is under a no burn order.

The department's website says there have been 259 man-made fires so far this year, including 60 over the past weekend.

urn:contentItem:4P00-MWD0-TX4V-K369-00000-00Alberta officials reopen major highway shut down due to forest fire2007-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSAlberta officials reopen major highway shut down due to forest fireCP

HIGH LEVEL, Alta. (CP) _ Alberta officials have reopened a major highway in northern Alberta that had been closed due to smoke from a forest fire.

Jerry Bellikka of Alberta Transportation had said earlier Thursday night that the situation was too dangerous for travellers and truckers.

But later in the evening, he said the wind had shifted, making it safer on Highway 35, from north of High Level, Alta., to the boundary with the Northwest Territories.

Bellika said the situation would be monitored overnight and there was also the chance the highway could be closed again.

The highway is a major transportation link between Alberta and the Northwest Territories and has lots of truck traffic.

Anastasia Drummond, a wildfire information officer with Sustainable Resource Development, said the fire was about four square kilometres in size and had started from a lightning strike Wednesday night.

Ground crews, helicopters and air tankers were working on the fire, 100 kilometres north of High Level.

''At this time it's not threatening any residences and the highway was closed for precautionary measures,'' she said. ''There's a lot of smoke in that area.''

Drummond said there are some small communities in the area that might see some smoke, but it wasn't yet causing them any problems.

urn:contentItem:5W88-S6G1-JDH1-C17S-00000-00Northern fire slows, winds push smoke into community2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. A5Northern fire slows, winds push smoke into communityLiam CaseyThe Canadian Press

A wildfire that has forced about 2,000 people from their homes in northwestern Ontario has begun to slow its spread, officials said Monday.

The forest fire near Pikangikum First Nation started on Wednesday and by Saturday it had grown to 36 square kilometres. A spokesperson for the Ministry of Resources and Forestry said that on Monday it covered 38 square kilometres.

"The fire has slowed growing, but obviously it's still something our guys are trying to get under control," Jolanta Kowalski said.

Kowalski said fire crews are bracing for a change in winds.

Environment Canada issued a special air quality statement Monday that the winds could sweep the smoke from Red Lake 14, as it's officially known, into the nearby First Nation.

"Smoke plumes from a forest fire east of Pikangikum have resulted in deteriorated air quality in the area," the agency said in its statement.

"Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk."

Nishnawbe Aski Nation, which represents 49 First Nation communities across northern Ontario, said about 2,000 people have been evacuated from the fly-in community, located about 500 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay, to other cities in Ontario and Manitoba.

The fire has damaged the broadband communications in the area, Nishnawbe Aski Nation said in a statement, knocking out phone and internet service.

"Bell technicians have been allowed to assess the damage in the community but due to weather delays they will not be able to fly into Pikangikum until Tuesday," the organization said.

(CP) - As firefighters struggled to gain control of the huge blaze engulfing homes on Penticton's outskirts, some residents complain the forest fire should have been put out before.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Someone dropped off a poster calling the Ministry of Forests procrastinators.</p><p>Others called the Pentiction Herald newspaper saying the fire should have been snuffed when it started - before it scorched more than 2,000 hectares.</p><p>"I wish it was that easy,'' said Maurice Davidson, a Ministry of Forests spokesman.</p><p>"It's not as easy as throwing a bucket of water on it and putting it out.''</p><p>Steep, rocky terrain limited the ability of fire crews to move safely into the area. Everything was done that could be done without putting firefighters' lives at risk, Davidson said.</p><p>"If we had 1,000 guys in there we would have had to evacuate 1,000 guys,'' a firefighter said.</p><p>There were descriptions of near chaos as the fire turned on crews. Some were trapped and had to be pulled out by helicopter. Others, unsure where the fire had spread, were guided out by aerial observers.</p><p>Still, firefighters made no excuses. Seeing a fire get out of hand, especially one on the verge of being controlled, is nothing to be proud of, they said.</p><p>"We've never lost a fire like this before,'' said one firefighter.</p><p>But another said they did the best they could, "given the cards we were dealt.''</p><p>Residents praised the evacuation process, saying they were given the time they needed to get out of endangered areas.</p><p>It could take anywhere from three days to three weeks to bring the fire under control, firefighters predicted. It all depends on the weather.</p><p>"We need help from Tanker One,'' one firefighter said, pointing up at the sky.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata (CP) - Plans to evacuate this community of 1,000 people were put on hold Sunday after firefighters tamed a forest fire that raced across the tree tops less than two kilometres from the town.</p><p>The fire, which was about 10 hectares in size when it started about 4 p.m., grew to more than 60 hectares in four hours.</p><p>-BODY- About 40 firefighters from the Ministry of Natural Resources and the community, as well as two ministry water bombers and three helicopters, were called in to fight the fire.</p><p>Ontario Provincial Police closed Highway 11 near Temagami, 130 kilometres north of North Bay, for several hours.</p><p>At one point the fire edged within 100 metres of a marina before a water bomber dropped a load on the flames.</p><p>"I've never seen anything like it. There were red and orange flames a half mile up in the sky,'' said Temagami Mayor Wayne Adair.</p><p>Plans were being made to turn an arena, about six kilometres north of town, into a temporary shelter for residents who had to be evacuated.</p><p>Firefighters were also battling a forest fire Sunday evening in Hekkla, about 25 kilometres west of Huntsville. Twelve homes were evacuated and several roads were closed.</p><p>Extremely dry conditions have led to bans on open air fires in the north.</p><p>(North Bay Nugget)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) _ The site of a major forest fire burning near Nova Scotia's south shore was starting to receive some much needed rain late Saturday afternoon.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Ground crews were continuing to work on the perimeter of the fire putting out hot spots in the Tobeatic Wilderness Area.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The fire will likely burn out if the area receives the rainfall forecasters have called for over the weekend, an official said.</p><p>The blaze has burned through about 800 hectares of forest in the reserve _ a 104,000-hectare expanse of provincially protected land containing waterways, old growth forests and barrens.</p><p>Officials said the fire was deep in the woods and no populated areas were threatened.</p><p>The fire was first noticed Tuesday evening in the Wallace Lake area of the preserve and has since burned a swath of land roughly five kilometres across.</p><p>Department of Natural Resources fire crews attacked the fire from the air using three water-dropping helicopters and a fixed-wing water bomber borrowed from Newfoundland.</p><p>It was deemed too dangerous for ground crews to approach the fire front until Friday.</p><p>The fire affects about one per cent of the protected Tobeatic preserve and undisturbed wilderness which is home to the largest native Nova Scotia remnant moose herd, several species of endangered plants and the protected Blanding's turtle.</p><p>Provincial forest fire crews also battled two smaller fires on Saturday _ one near Ashdale, which burned about four hectares, and a small brush fire near Whycocomagh.</p><p>Forest fires have blazed through nearly 1,200 hectares of woodland so far this year, six times more than the area consumed by fires last year.</p><p>(Halifax Chronicle-Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "We expect to get a cat line around all of the fire."</p><p>While a fireguard can only prevent the fire from creeping along the ground, it is another step toward bringing the fire under control, Strickland said.</p><p>The Chisholm fire has proven to be a difficult dragon to slay. When the winds were driving the fire last Monday, it was rocketing embers 10 kilometres in advance of a 100-metre wall of flame.</p><p>And late Friday, wind-driven flames jumped fireguards on the fire's southwestern boundary. Water bombers were able to beat them back, but not before the fire consumed another 100 hectares of forest, Strickland said.</p><p>There were no communities in the area where the fire broke through the fireguard, he said.</p><p>Residents of Smith and Hondo, who have been evacuated previously, remained on evacuation alert.</p><p>Although moderate winds were blowing over the fire Saturday, firefighters experienced a less anxious day on the firelines.</p><p>The fire, which began near a CN rail line May 23, has already destroyed nine homes in the hamlet of Chisholm.</p><p>The province has spent more than $7 million fighting the blaze, 150 km north of Edmonton.</p><p>Nearly 400 forest fires in the province so far this year have destroyed 20 homes and more than 1,400 square kilometres of forest.</p><p>About 1,055 firefighters were fighting a total of 22 fires in the province Saturday, including three which were burning out of control. They received reinforcements late Friday with the arrival of 80 more firefighters from Ontario and 80 from B.C., bringing the total number of out-of-province firefighters to 620.</p><p>Already, Alberta forest fires have eaten up half the province's $60 million fire budget.</p><p>The fires are being blamed on tinder dry conditions stemming from one of the driest winters in 130 years.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>AP; Battling The Flames - Ontario firefighter Jennifer Gregoruk holds a fire hose for a fellow crew member at Among those forced to change their plans was a Canada AM television crew that had planned to broadcast live out of Dawson City today.</p><p>The show will now be broadcast from Whitehorse.</p><p>The Minto Resort, midway between Carmacks and Pelly Crossing, got an unexpected rush of business Monday night as stranded travellers poured into the picturesque resort on the east banks of the Yukon River.</p><p>"We had the coffee pot on all night,'' said resort spokesman Pat Van Bibber.</p><p>Keith Kepke, the Northern Development Department's fire management head for the Yukon, said the blaze is a big one and won't be brought under control for some time.</p><p>The fire is burning in the forest canopy and sending a column of grey smoke up to 6,000 metres in the air.</p><p>About 30 firefighters are battling the blaze. (CP) _ Firefighters battling a forest fire in northern Manitoba are getting help from the weather forecast.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Cool, wet conditions are expected to continue this week.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>A downpour on Sunday dramatically improved a blaze that threatened the community of Bird and the adjoining Fox Lake First Nation.</p><p>The communities are 800 kilometres north of Winnipeg.</p><p>Some residents of the reserve who had been evacuated as a precaution are being allowed to return home.</p><p>Manitoba Conservation says three northern fires are still burning but are under control.</p><p>The fire near Bird grew to 17 square kilometres from seven square kilometres in less than 24 hours late last week, and had reached 21 square kilometres by Sunday morning.</p><p>Residents were put on evacuation notice as shifting winds brought the fire close to their communities.</p><p>About 40 reserve residents at risk _ young children, the elderly and those with respiratory problems _ were evacuated as a precaution. That order was cancelled later Sunday and residents began returning home as the change in weather eased the fire.</p><p>While the weekend brought warmth and clear skies to southern Manitobans, cool weather and rain hit the north.</p><p>"They got more than an inch,'' said Tom Mirus, Manitoba Conservation field supervisor. "It was a nice slow, soaking rain.''</p><p>That allowed Manitoba Conservation to reduce its team of firefighters to 20 from 55.</p><p>Mirus said as of Sunday there have been 79 wildfires this year, compared to 70 by June 19 last year.</p><p>"But this is still a very, very quiet year,'' he said.</p><p>The 20-year average for June 19 is 227 fires that destroyed 165 square kilometres.</p><p>(Winnipeg Free Press)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5NYM-0YP1-JDH3-G4YP-00000-00Parry Sound fire tower model at the museum2017-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYPg. 1Parry Sound fire tower model at the museum

PARRY SOUND - This model, made by John Studd and donated to the Museum in 1998, is a reproduction of the fire observation tower that sits next to The Museum on Tower Hill. Following the 'Great Fire of 1916' the Ontario government passed the Forest Fire Prevention Act in 1917. Peter McEwen was appointed District Forester of the Ontario Forestry Branch in Parry Sound in 1922 and with 75 forest rangers began to organize an effective forest protection system. By 1927, the tower was one of 27 across the district used in forest fire detection. Work was seasonal, beginning in the spring and ending in the fall and towermen had to report to headquarters in Parry Sound every hour during daylight hours. Using an alidade, a long metal instrument with a fine sight placed on top of a round map glued to a table that could be swung 360 degrees, towermen would get a bearing on a fire and radio the results. When multiple towermen identified a fire the rangers were able to pinpoint the exact location. With the advance in technology the tower network fire detection system was abandoned and replaced with the use of aircraft by 1966.

The fire tower at the Museum is unique as it was also designed as an observation tower with stairs, rather than the typical ladder, leading to the top. In 1928, Peter McEwen opened the tower to the public. He recognized Parry Sound as a tourist destination and wanted to get people interested in forest fire prevention. Eventually the tower was deemed unsafe and dismantled. In 1975 a new tower was erected and once again opened to the public. The current tower sits at 96 feet and has 131 stairs. Look out for The Forest Fire Exhibition at the Museum opening this month.

"It's a precuationary move. Hopefully we can get in there and get a good handle on it."</p><p>She was optimistic the evacuation will be only temporary and won't require them to be away overnight.</p><p>"We're hoping that once we get the machinery in and the winds die down a wee bit they can safely go home."</p><p>She said forest fire officials are diverting resources from the other end of the 148 square km fire to protect the community.</p><p>About 250 firefighters are fighting the blaze, which is burning along both banks of the Athabasca River, about 150 km north of Edmonton.</p><p>Residents of Chisholm were rousted from their beds Friday night when the fire crept with 400 metres of the community.</p><p>The fire, which is burning south of the hamlet, has destroyed several outbuildings and vehicles, but so far no homes have been lost to flames.</p><p>Meanwhile, Alberta firefighters got some reinforcements yesterday to help them fight 23 blazes in the province, including six which are burning out of control.</p><p>About 100 initial attack firefighters arrived from Ontario to help the 700 Albertans already on fire lines.</p><p>Fires have already consumed 285 square kilometres of Alberta forest.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5D18-0GY1-JBVR-31VV-00000-00Water bomber that crashed on lake during forest fire was overloaded, TSB report2014-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisATLANTICWater bomber that crashed on lake during forest fire was overloaded, TSB reportWater bomber overloaded, safety board reportThe Canadian Press

HALIFAX - A water bomber owned by the Newfoundland and Labrador government that crashed on Moosehead Lake last year took on too much water, which was a central cause in the plane failing to get airborne, the Transportation Safety Board of Canada said Thursday.

The aircraft owned by the government's air service division came to rest upright on the lake and partially submerged, the board said in releasing its investigation report into the accident.

There were no injuries to the two crew members, but the board said the aircraft was destroyed.

The Bombardier CL-415 amphibious aircraft left Wabush on July 3, 2013, in mid-afternoon to fight a nearby forest fire.

A short time later, the water bomber touched down on Moosehead Lake to scoop a load of water. The safety board said about 40 seconds later, the captain initiated a left-hand turn and almost immediately lost control.

"The investigation also found that the flight crew was occupied with other flight activities during the scooping run and did not notice that the water quantity exceeded the predetermined limit until after the tanks had filled to capacity," the board said in a news release. "The flight crew then decided to continue the takeoff with the aircraft in an overweight condition."

The crew waited to be rescued by a boat from the top of the wing.

The board said its investigation also found a switch that controls probes used to scoop water from a lake was inadvertently moved to the auto position from manual. The switch is not included on the pilots' checklist, although that has changed since the crash.

"If a checklist does not include a critical item, and flight crews are expected to rely on their memory, then there is a risk that the item will be missed and safety could be jeopardized," the board said.

It said the government has made some safety changes since the crash, including to the way safety gear is stored and secured, and it has installed portable satellite telephones in its aircraft. Water bomber pilots and maintenance personnel will also get new training.

However, about 12 millimetres of rain on the weekend did help firefighters make some progress on the ground.</p><p>But crews were trying to stamp out flare-ups yesterday about 21 kilometres west of Prince Albert near the community of Crutwell, which was evacuated on the weekend.</p><p>Residents of Prince Albert, a city of almost 40,000 people nestled in the northern forest belt, were on edge as smoke wafted overhead. The fire has charred an area of about 88 square kilometres.</p><p>Foster said the fire centre receives plenty of calls from nervous residents when smoke becomes thicker or flames are visible from the city, 120 kilometres north of Saskatoon.</p><p>"A lot of people who live here have been talking about this (the possibility of fire) for a long time," Foster said. "When you live in a massive forest and it's been dry for years … well, they say if something were to happen, it wouldn't be good."</p><p>The blaze started out as two separate fires on Friday but by Saturday they had merged into one.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source MARIE, Ont.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont. (CP) - Continuing dry and windy conditions are adding to the forest fire threat as crews continue to battle several large blazes across the area.</p><p>Bob Thomas, a spokesman for the Ministry of Natural Resources, said weekend lightning strikes accompanied by very little rain have created "hold-over lightning fires."</p><p>That means lightning hit the trunks of damp trees and caused them to smoulder, Thomas said. Once conditions are dry again, the trunks can burst into flames.</p><p>"We've had quite a few show up in the northeast in the past couple of days,'' Thomas said Thursday.</p><p>Fifty fires were burning throughout the province today, with 33 of them newly reported since Tuesday.</p><p>The restricted fire zone in the northeastern region, which bans all open burning other than in approved campground sites, has been extended until the dry conditions can be relieved by significant amounts of rainfall, Thomas said.</p><p>"This wind won't help the existing fires. It could fan the flames,'' he said.</p><p>A fire south of Wawa, near Caramat, was about 2,000 hectares in size Wednesday. It's the largest active fire in the Algoma region, Thomas said.</p><p>"We have a team assigned to that one now and there's another fire, about 250 hectares, south of Chapleau near Shoals Provincial Park that started in a plantation area and moved into mixed wood,'' he said.</p><p>Meanwhile, NorthwesternOntario has received significant rainfall, easing the forest fire danger there. (Sault Star)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Four months ago, Jennifer<br/>White, like a lot of other people, lost everything. And since then, as the<br/>donations have poured in to rebuild homes, in the village of Louis Creek, just<br/>north of Kamloops, Jennifer has waited and she has waited hoping that her<br/>Christmas wish will come true. Here's CTV's Sarah Galashan.</p><p>SARAH GALASHAN [Reporter]: The tree is fake but the tears are real. Jennifer<br/>White knows that come Christmas this is as close to a home as she'll get.</p><p>JENNIFER WHITE [Forest Fire Victim]: It is not home.</p><p>GALASHAN: She lives in a rented leaky trailer, spending her days filling out<br/>countless forms for financial aid and making copies of photographs for fear they<br/>could be lost next time.</p><p>WHITE: As soon as I start feeling normal, I feel like something's going to<br/>happen, something awful is going to happen like…</p><p>GALASHAN: Because it wasn't long ago that something did. The forest fires<br/>that nearly wiped her tiny town off the map burned her home and the mill<br/>where her husband works to the ground. Her memories, her wedding rings<br/>reduced to rubble. The most devastating of all, the house, built in the 1930's.<br/>was considered too close to the highway to be insured. Suddenly, they had<br/>nothing.</p><p>WHITE: This is where we lived.<br/><br/></p><p>GALASHAN: Now the foundation is covered with a fresh blanket of snow.<br/>Nearby, a fresh start, thanks to the $45,000.00 they received in donations<br/>made by Canadians from across the country. They're rebuilding here on the<br/>same property where they lived for so many years. It might not be their dream<br/>home, but at this point any home is a dream.</p><p>WHITE: We are so grateful to the people who donated the money. Otherwise,<br/>we would not have this. It's so great.</p><p>GALASHAN: In fact it's barely a frame, built by a crew of family members, but<br/>like hundreds of others who lost their homes last summer, for them this is…</p><p>WHITE: What a wonderful Christmas present.</p><p>GALASHAN: Even if it is one of the last homes to go up.</p><p>WHITE: And this is our view here.</p><p>GALASHAN: The forest, once lush and green, is now full of charred Christmas<br/>trees. It's a painful reminder this time of year.</p><p>WHITE: There's so many burned trees here I just couldn't go and cut down a<br/>live living tree.</p><p>GALASHAN: And the reason why sometimes both the smile and the tree are<br/>artificial. Sarah Galashan, CTV News, Louis Creek, British Columbia.</p><p>BAICHWAL: When we return, a gift that keeps giving all year around. Three<br/>decades of giving and receiving by Canada's famous People Players. That's a<br/>CTV success story. Stay with us.</p><p>[COMMERCIAL BREAK]</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CTV2003</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">211506</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="457"/><timeReceived>23:00:00 - A forest fire that started yesterday afternoon in the Chapleau area near Wawa, Ontario, has burned through at least 22 hydro poles and caused a power outage affecting approximately 2,000 local residents, including 470 Hydro One customers. As the fires continue to burn, Hydro One crews are not able to access the area in order to assess the full nature and extent of damage to electrical equipment. Crews have been mobilized and are ready to repair the system once clearance is received from the local Fire Warden.

"Safety of the public and our employees is our number one concern," said Myles D'Arcey, Senior Vice-President, Customer Operations, Hydro One. "Hydro One crews are on hand, ready to respond and assess the extent of the damage. Once we receive clearance, we will respond as quickly as possible to safely repair damaged equipment and restore power to the area."

Estimated restoration time cannot be determined until the fire is under control and crews are able to access the scene. It is expected that it could take several days to repair the system in order to restore power. The Company will continue to provide updates as the situation evolves.

Hydro One crews are staging near the site with helicopters and off-road equipment on hand to ship in the new poles and materials needed to restring the power line.

Hydro One delivers electricity safely, reliably and responsibly to homes and businesses across the province of Ontario and owns and operates Ontario's 29,000 km high-voltage transmission network that delivers electricity to large industrial customers and municipal utilities, and a 123,000 km low-voltage distribution system that serves about 1.3 million end-use customers and smaller municipal utilities in the province. Hydro One is wholly owned by the Province of Ontario.

(CP) _ Saskatchewan foresters are fired up over a new system that uses video cameras to get an early jump on wildfires.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The new technology is getting a workout at the provincial forest fire control centre, outside Prince Albert, Sask.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Kris Johnson, a fire operations specialist with the Forest Engineering Research Institute of Canada, says the system has potential to spot blazes early.</p><p>"If you can hit them when they're small, you can save yourself a world of grief,'' he said.</p><p>Traditionally, human spotters atop a tower or in an airplane have searched for smoke, Johnson said. Calls from people on the ground who spot smoke also alert the fire centre.</p><p>But two years ago, the provincial government closed its fire towers for safety reasons. That prompted Saskatchewan Environment to explore new detection methods.</p><p>This spring, Johnson learned about Envirovision Solutions cameras at a conference on emerging fire-detection technology in Hinton, Alta.</p><p>South African physicist Gavin Hough originally designed motion-detecting software to study Antarctica's aurora australis, the southern hemisphere's version of the northern lights. But after noting the similarities between the motion of the lights and the motion of fire, Hough applied the system to wildfire detection.</p><p>A camera mounted to a tower on top of the forest fire centre can rotate 360 degrees in less than a second and scan a 40-kilometre radius. The electronic eye can focus on individual buildings within the city or swing its lens toward structures outside its limits.</p><p>The system combines the video surveillance with global positioning system and geographic information system technologies.</p><p>Existing cellphone and radio towers could be used, which could cut costs, Johnson said. As well, GPS and GIS technology could provide firefighting crews with precise information about local topography, the property owner or if a burning permit had been issued for the location.</p><p>"Saskatchewan has a good detection system going,'' Johnson said. "This is a question of how to make it better.''</p><p>(Prince Albert Daily Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:7VTX-G920-Y9NS-W0HG-00000-00Dozens evacuated from homes near Canwood, Sask., due to forest fire2009-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSDozens evacuated from homes near Canwood, Sask., due to forest fireCP

CANWOOD, Sask. _ Dozens of people remain evacuated from their rural homes due to a forest fire measuring five square kilometres near Canwood, Sask.

Most left their homes on Saturday and strong winds and dry conditions on Sunday are making it difficult for crews to fight the blaze.

Officials are warning other residents in the area northwest of Prince Albert to be on alert.

So far no houses or private property have been damaged by the fire.

But officials with Saskatchewan Environment say the blaze continues to grow and is not yet under control.

Spokesman Steve Roberts says the blaze started small and was driven in one direction by the winds, making it a long, thin line of flame.

Lyndon Pease left his farm on Saturday but was allowed to return on Sunday.

However, officials have told him to keep his bags packed and be ready to leave again.

''It's kind of scary once you get a phone call and they say, 'you've gotta go, it's time to go,' you know, holy smokes,'' Pease said.

''It's bad enough that you get a call from your anniversary, and you get a call from somebody that says, 'I think your house is on fire.' Well, it wasn't that bad but it isn't something you want to hear.''

There are more than 60 people on the ground fighting the blaze, with two water bombers and three helicopters helping from the air.

''Crews will continue to work with heavy equipment putting mineral guards around,'' said Roberts.

''Tankers will continue to supply, in this case, water with our scooper aircraft to the fire to cool the fire behaviour down. Ground crews will then work to cool it on the ground itself, widening the perimeters and prevent fire spread.''

The cause of the fire is not known.

(CTV Prince Albert)

Even the village nursing station is divided in two, with Inuit patients on one side of the building and Cree on the other.</p><p>-BODY- Monday, however, the two solitudes of this remote post on the southeast shore of Hudson Bay worked together to evacuate their village in the face of an advancing forest fire.</p><p>They climbed on board Armed Forces Hercules transports and Hydro Quebec aircraft flown up from southern Quebec. Local leaders, however, were careful to load equal numbers of Cree and Inuit on departing planes, for fear of upsetting either side.</p><p>"They didn't want to take out one community first, they did it equally,'' said Rev. Tom Martin, reached by telephone Monday.</p><p>Forest fires are unheard of on the treeless tundra of Arctic Quebec, but Great Whale River sits on the northern reaches of the tree line, 1,200 kilometres north of Montreal.</p><p>On Sunday afternoon, after weeks of dry weather, a cooking fire at a Cree hunting camp ignited a five-kilometre-wide blaze that within hours was threatening to jump the river that skirts the southern edge of the village.</p><p>By 5 p.m., Cree and Inuit leaders declared a state of emergency and decided to call in military aircraft from Trenton, Ont., to airlift the community's 1,500 residents.</p><p>Six aircraft, including a plan from Air Inuit, flew through the night from the community's gravel runway, ferrying the sick, the young and the elderly to the safety of La Grande, Que.</p><p>By 7 a.m. Monday, with 250 residents removed, early morning thunderstorms had dampened the fire and evacuation plans were put on hold.</p><p>The fire was reduced to smouldering hot spots by Monday night. (National Post)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) _ The forest fire index may reach extreme levels in parts of New Brunswick on Tuesday as temperatures approach record levels.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A total of 21 fires were reported on Saturday and Sunday in the province, with another three spotted on Monday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"We've had a few small fires but the ground crews are taking care of that, our aircraft have been on the ground all day,'' said Paul Gilmore, the provincial duty officer overseeing the Department of Natural Resources' response to forest fires.</p><p>Burn permits throughout southern New Brunswick and stretching as far north as Perth-Andover and Newcastle have been cancelled.</p><p>Temperatures will be between 26 C and 29 C on Tuesday, with southwesterly winds reaching speeds of up to 20 kilometres per hour. Some areas may see temperatures of up to 30 C.</p><p>Temperatures will come down to seasonal normals for the rest of the week.</p><p>Forest rangers wishing for a reprieve from the danger of fires will only receive scattered showers on Wednesday and Thursday, said Environment Canada meteorologist Claude Cote.</p><p>Fires reported Monday were in the Fredericton area, north of Bathurst and one located between Musquash and Pennfield.</p><p>Human actions were believed to have caused all of the fires.</p><p>Forest fire fuels such as grass and pine needles are extremely dry right now.</p><p>There have been 68 fires in New Brunswick so far this year.</p><p>(New BrunswickTelegraph-Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20030519CPCPA1536</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:48MW-M2P0-01G6-94SS-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="233"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="19" month="05" year="2003"><dateText>May 19, 2003 Monday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>FORESTRY; urn:contentItem:5SWG-T981-F105-62YV-00000-00'They are angels of mercy': Hanmer man shares Key River evacuation story2018-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1'They are angels of mercy': Hanmer man shares Key River evacuation story

KEY RIVER - A week-long sojourn at an island cottage they'd rented on Georgian Bay was supposed to be a relaxing getaway for Hanmer resident Kevin Shanahan and friend Chris Ransom.

Shanahan describes the cottage - located about a 45-minute boat ride from the Key River Marina - as "heaven on earth."

The island, located about 500 metres from shore, is also the perfect place for Ransom's three dogs to swim and enjoy a little freedom.

But thanks to the large, out-of-control forest fire known as Parry Sound 33 - the fire reached 4,841 hectares Saturday - their vacation came to an abrupt end Friday evening.

Along with others staying at boat-access-only cottages in the Key River area, they were evacuated.

Shanahan said they first saw the forest fire Wednesday, but the water bombers seemed to be doing a good job of putting it out.

"But it really flared up Friday morning, and it went fast," he said. "That's when I started getting worried."

They received a visit from two Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry officials in a boat at around 10 a.m. Friday morning, who informed them they may have to evacuate, and asked for their cell number.

Shanahan said they did have a small motorboat at the island that they could have used to escape the forest fire should they need to, but it wouldn't have been much use out on the big water.

Navigating the area is also tricky, and best left to those familiar with the waterways.

At around 4 p.m., hydro on the island went out, so Shanahan was cooking some dinner on the barbecue when they received a call from the MNRF to say they were going to evacuate them shortly, and to pack only the essentials.

Fortunately, taking the dogs with them on the boat wasn't a problem, but Shanahan's health did pose a challenge, as they would be travelling through two kilometres of heavy smoke.

Shanahan, a 73-year-old cancer survivor, only has one lung, and that lung has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

So the MNRF officials phoned the fire department, who met the group in another boat before they got into the heavy smoke.

A firefighter fitted Shanahan with an oxygen mask and kept a close eye on his breathing until they got safely to shore.

"Once I got into the smoke, I knew if I didn't have that mask on, I would be in a lot of trouble," he said.

Both sides of the river had been burned, although there weren't any large flames - only small flare-ups in bushes. The water bombers were roaring overhead, coming so close you could almost touch them if you reached up.

Shanahan is philosophical about the experience.

He said he's been "to hell and back" this past year - his wife passed away in December and he's had some health challenges - so if he could survive all that, he knew he could survive this experience too.

Shanahan said he does want to thank all of the officials involved in the evacuations as a result of the Parry Sound 33 forest fire, as well as those fighting the blaze.

"They are angels of mercy," he said. "They made us feel comfortable, they made us feel confident."

urn:contentItem:4SMM-DYS0-TX4V-K0CS-00000-00Manitoba town safe for now after forest fire moves through, scattering embers2008-05-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSManitoba town safe for now after forest fire moves through, scattering embersSTEVE LAMBERTCP

WINNIPEG _ Firefighters used sprinklers and water bombers to guard the evacuated homes of a tiny northern Manitoba community as a raging forest fire moved around and through it Thursday night.

Despite flying embers that started small blazes wherever the water's protection didn't reach, only two sheds were lost to the flames, said Tom Mirus, head of Manitoba's fire program.

''It was quite a nose-to-nose fight for a while there, but they got everything.''

He said Sherridon was considered safe Thursday night, though he added the community is not quite out of danger.

The wind was expected to shift, pushing the fire back south, and hot spots might still ignite.

''We're going to be up through the night making sure there's no embers that are smouldering away anywhere,'' he said.

Three water bombers attacked the 60 square-kilometre blaze outside Sherridon as more than 50 firefighters sprayed buildings with water to protect them from burning embers.

''Any spot fires that came up were put out quickly, and everything, as far as I know, has been successful,'' said Mirus.

The community's 150 residents were evacuated a day earlier as the flames threatened to close off the only road out of town.

The fire, some 150 kilometres north of The Pas near the Saskatchewan boundary, was the most serious of several that were burning across the tinder-dry forests of northern Manitoba. The province called in fire crews from Ontario to help out.

Further east in Norway House, a smaller fire that had forced 1,000 residents in outlying areas of the sprawling reserve to move into the centre of the community was contained Thursday. Band officials were optimistic conditions would soon allow residents to return home.

''The fire is contained but not under control,'' said Norway House Chief Marcel Balfour.

Near the Ontario boundary, heavy smoke from other fires prompted partial evacuations of people with health problems in St. Theresa Point and Wasagamack. Both fires were out of control, but crews were managing to hold the lines nearest both communities.

Firefighters were expecting a bit of help from the weather forecast, which called for up to five millimetres of rain and higher humidity levels.

''That's not enough rain, but we'll take what we can get,'' Mirus said.

The dry weather has made for a busy start to Manitoba's forest fire season. Just weeks after the snow melted off the ground in northern areas, the province has recorded 152 fires, all of them caused by human activity.

One large blaze appeared to have been started by forestry equipment, Mirus said, while the Sherridon fire is believed to have been sparked by a train.

''Just from the train somehow, either a hotbox on the train or a brake shoe falling off or sparks from the stack,'' he said.

The fire's progress was slowed somewhat by heavy rain, said John Cook of the provincial forest fire centre.</p><p>Stiff winds had threatened to drive the 45,000-hectare fire toward town, but damp, cool weather and high humidity helped firefighters hold it 15 km to the southeast, Cook said.</p><p>On Wednesday, firefighters concentrated their efforts on three spot blazes, which started when the fire jumped the Reindeer River, which forms a natural barrier on the fire's northwest side.</p><p>"They managed to hold that fire. "Control' is not a word you can use on 45,000 hectares on fire up there," Cook said.</p><p>About 150 firefighters were heartened to hear the wind was expected to shift Wednesday night, turning the fire back on itself. The largest, which started May 13, was burning over 190,000 hectares on the Primrose air weapons range in the northwest.</p><p>Seventy-five firefighters in Manitoba also got a bit of a boost from Wednesday's weather as they battled a fire near Wabowden, 650 km north of Winnipeg. A few millimetres of rain and a change in wind direction helped them gain enough control to allow 337 Wabowden residents to return home Wednesday afternoon. The residents had been ordered out Tuesday.</p><p>Syd Robak, director of Natural Resources northeast region, said he hopes to have a solid ring around the entire fire in the next 24 hours.</p><p>At NORTH BAY - UPDATE (9 a.m., Saturday, July 28) By the evening of Friday, July 27 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports there were 43 forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 13 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held under control or being observed.

There was one new fire confirmed, North Bay 119, located eight kilometres southwest of Lachford was 0.1 hectares and is already out.

A total of three fires were extinguished today.

River Valley Fire Cluster

This cluster includes two fires - North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both of these fires are being held. North Bay 25 is being monitored to the west of the cluster, which is now under control at 200 hectares.

There are 135 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, Alberta, British Columbia, Nova Scotia, Saskatchewan and Mexico.

Crews made progress on all fires in the cluster today working on the southside of North Bay 42 and continued to work the perimeter on North Bay 62 while other crews continued to recover equipment from the fire.

Some smoke was visible on North Bay 25 while crews worked to extinguish hot spots.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster

The North Bay 72 fire remains at 27,579 hectares and is not yet under control. The fire was scanned from the air in the early morning of July 27. Infrared scanning identifies areas that are holding heat so fire rangers can walk the fire and extinguish hot spots.

The Incident Management Team assigned to this cluster continues to observe North Bay fires 18, 19, 46, 59, and 61. These fires will also be scanned using infrared technology in the coming days.

NORTH BAY - UPDATE (11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26): By the evening of Thursday, July 26, there were 45 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed.

River Valley Fire Cluster

The River Valley Fire Cluster includes two fires: North Bay 62 and North Bay 42. Both fires are now being held, meaning that the fires are not expected to spread under current conditions. The ministry is continuing to monitor North Bay 25 to the west of the cluster, which is now under control.

There are 154 people working on these fires including firefighters from Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Nova Scotia and Mexico.

Crews took advantage of the cooler, dry day to make solid progress on all fires. On North Bay 42, crews continued to secure the perimeter on the north side as well as working on hot spots on the west side. For North Bay 62, crews continued to work the perimeter of the fire while some crews began to recover equipment from the fire.

Crews completed removal of sprinkler protection from all structures.

Temagami Fire Cluster:

Fire activity has proven more manageable on fires in the Temagami cluster with all active fires in this cluster now classified as either being held or under control.

Lady Evelyn Fire Cluster:

North Bay 72 remains at 27,579 hectares and is listed as not under control. However, the overcast skies and wet weather of late has allowed firefighters to consolidate hose lines along the perimeter. While there is much work still to be done, progress is being made daily.

Front line staff continue to work with heavy equipment operators to establish dozer guards in areas where this type of suppression is suitable. This goes a long way to secure the perimeter of the fire.

The Incident Management Team continues to observe North Bay 18, 19, 46, 59 and 61. While these fires have been quiet, they are not considered out.

Currently there are 10 helicopters assigned to this cluster. Transitioning of staff is ongoing as personnel depart for their home locations and new staff arrive. Crews arrived from northwestern Ontario today and more are expected from Saskatchewan tomorrow.

The ministry continues to have firefighters from British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland, Northwest Territories and Mexico work on this cluster. Restricted Fire Zone expanded

Due to the extreme fire hazard, several recent periods of heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry has expanded the Restricted Fire Zone. This expansion of the current Restricted Fire Zone will be in effect as of 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday, July 24, and remain in place until further notice.

The expanded Restricted Fire Zone now includes Zones 24, 25 and 26 which would include areas south of the French River, including Parry Sound, from Georgian Bay east to the Quebec border, including Algonquin Provincial Park and from Renfrew north to Mattawa.

To date, the current Restricted Fire Zone covers Zones 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 24, 25 and 26 and restrictions will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for an outline of the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris, is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

Ontario is receiving support from across Canada, the United States and Mexico to assist with the fire situation. Additional personnel and equipment are expected to arrive in the province in the coming days, including ignition specialists from Parks Canada.

Travel restrictions

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of North Bay, Kirkland Lake and Sudbury Districts where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity.

The Order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions.

This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

All travel and use of the following roads are prohibited: McLaren's Road, Gibbons Road, Baie-Jeanne Road, South Pardo Road, Beauty Lake Road, St. Joseph's Road, George Gordon and Iron Lake Road, Cooke Lake Road, Liskeard Lumber Road, Klock Lake Road, Crane Lake Road, Roadhouse Tower Road, Indian Bay Road, Mountain Lake Road, and Goulard Road starting at Lower Goose Falls.

All modes of travel/access into Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater, Obabika River, Makobe-Grays River, Solace and Sturgeon River Provincial Parks, and all Crown lands is prohibited.

Use of the Red Squirrel Lake Road beyond the Barmac Gate is prohibited.

All use and occupation of Crown land on or within 500 metres of all described closed roads is prohibited.

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for non-recreational purposes, please call North Bay District at 705-475-5546 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) or Kirkland Lake District at 705-568-3240 (8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.) to request a travel authorization permit. For requesting access to Red Squirrel Lake Road, please call North Bay District. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

See the restricted travel and access areas on this PDF map (Note: this map gets updated regularly).

Smoke concerns

Many Ontario residents have reported smoke drift in their communities. Smoky conditions are expected to continue as a number of fires remain active throughout the northeast region until weather patterns and fire activity change.

The Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

To report a forest fire located north of the French and Mattawa rivers, please dial 310-FIRE (3473)

To report a forest fire located south of the French or Mattawa rivers, please dial 911.

Follow Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry on Twitter @ONForestFires

For up to date information on current fires in the province or to check the forest fire hazard in your area, visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

N3Holding PM's feet to the fire with humourFundraising duo say pipeline with forest fire fumes could awake PM to climate changePerrin Grauer StarMetro Vancouver More on the fires at thestar.com/vancouver

Pumping smoke from B.C. wildfires into the "sexy boudoir" of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is the hook being used by a pair of Vancouverites to raise funds for disaster relief.

Sean Devlin, a member of the Sh*tHarperDid advocacy group known for its comedic critique of Canadian politics and politicians, started an Indiegogo campaign with his colleague Shane Supernova on Thursday. The facetious goal is to build a pipeline to fill Trudeau's residence with wildfire smoke from B.C.'s blazes to drive home how federal energy policy is contributing to climate change.

"A bunch of us woke up and there was just smoke everywhere," Devlin said in an interview, adding the surreal experience was at once alarming and motivating. He and Supernova came up with the image of piping the smoke directly into Trudeau's bedroom as a way to connect the federal leader with what might seem like a distant, West Coast problem.

"And it was just a funny joke," he said. "We thought by using the joke to raise money to help people who are harmed by this stuff, we could find another way to hold (Trudeau's) feet to the fire."

Devlin and Supernova's goal is to use this far-fetched scenario to raise awareness around how the federal government's purchase of the Trans Mountain pipeline signals a disinterest in taking the impact of fossil fuel production on climate change seriously. In doing so, they hope to encourage donations to their fund, which will go to support wildfire relief in Canada, and to support the impoverished community of Anibong, Leyte, in the Philippines, whose members continue to suffer since the category 5 typhoon Haiyan displaced more than four million people in November, 2013.

Alex Schenk of the Rescue Co-ordination Centre here said he was told the plane, a four-engine Lockheed Electra, may have exploded on impact.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Under those circumstances it's unlikely the crew survived, said Peter Murphy, acting regional manager for the federal Transportation Safety Board.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"It seems unlikely at this point, but I am not going to jump to that conclusion,'' said Murphy. "They have to confirm that.</p><p>"This is a very large aircraft and it cruises at a pretty good clip.''</p><p>Schenk said he'd been told by RCMP that the effort was a recovery operation, not a search-and-rescue effort.</p><p>But a Cranbrook RCMP spokesman said he could not confirm Schenk's information nor whether the crew had been killed.</p><p>Late Wednesday, the RCMP said in a statement that emergency personnel had been unable to access the crash site _ about 10 kilometres southeast of the Cranbrook airport. Several fires were burning in the area.</p><p>"Fire crews have established a fire guard around the 5.4 hectare fire and are expecting containment early (Thursday),'' the statement said.</p><p>Murphy said the crash apparently happened just after the plane dumped a load of flame-retardant materials.</p><p>Tankers normally fly low to the ground during fire-fighting runs and the plane could have had as much as 8,000 kilograms of fuel on board, said Murphy.</p><p>He said it was too early to speculate on what might have caused the crash but added crashes by this type of plane are rare.</p><p>The aerial tanker was owned by a Air Spray Ltd. of Edmonton, which owns fire-suppression planes in British Columbia and Alberta.</p><p>The locally based plane was helping fight a forest fire in the area at the time of the crash.</p><p>"We understand one of our aircraft has crashed and we are trying to get the details now and find out who the crews are,'' Air Spray manager Richard Covlin said from Edmonton. "Our crew was working at Cranbrook.''</p><p>Covlin said it was believed two crew members were aboard but their identities would not be released until their families were notified.</p><p>"All of our crews are extremely experienced people,'' said Covlin. "They have to be to work in those circumstances.''</p><p>According to the company's Web site, Air Spray owns and operates 35 aircraft, providing forest-fire protection for the Alberta and B.C. "We've done such a great job of <br/>putting forest fires out for the past century, that what we've done is create <br/>a huge fuel source," said Turley. "We have to prepare ourselves to deal with <br/>the fires by building safer homes and communities. We don't necessarily want <br/>to put the fires out as much as we want to be able to survive the fires." <br/>    BCAA Insurance handled more than 220 fire-related insurance claims, <br/>including several total losses as a result of 2003's forest fires. <br/>    "As one of the largest providers of home insurance in the province, BCAA <br/>saw first hand the devastation many of our policyholders faced," said Scott <br/>McBride, Vice President, BCAA Insurance. "As important as it is to be armed <br/>with home insurance to cover your belongings in a forest fire, most of us <br/>would rather not be faced with having to start from scratch.</p><p>That's why it's <br/>important for homeowners to take steps to minimize that possibility." <br/>    BCAA encourages homeowners to practice the following safety measures to <br/>protect themselves and their belongings against a forest fire:</p><p>    1.  Surround your home with defensible space. Focus on the 10 metres <br/>        surrounding your home. Clear trees and brush which can act as fuel. <br/>        Create fuel breaks with driveways, gravel and lawns when at all <br/>        possible.</p><p>    2.  "Firesmart" your house. Invest in building or remodeling your home <br/>        with safer materials that have a better chance of withstanding fire <br/>        embers. Homes with non combustible roofs, such as slate, metal, clay <br/>        or tile are rewarded by some insurance companies with discounts on <br/>        their insurance premiums.</p><p>        Ensure your roof is free of combustible debris, such as overhanging <br/>        trees, or pine needles and other vegetation which act as fuel for <br/>        airborne sparks and embers.</p><p>    3.  Assess your building lot. Make sure your address is clearly visible <br/>        from the road and ensure your community is marked with visible, <br/>        non-combustible signs.</p><p>    4.  Assess belongings around your property. Always store firewood away <br/>        from your house. Avoid keeping combustible materials, such as propane <br/>        and natural gas tanks, under decks or porches.</p><p>    5.  Be "Firesmart" inside your house. Keep one or more fire extinguishers <br/>        charged and easily accessible. Dispose of hot embers from a fireplace <br/>        or barbeque in a metal container.</p><p>    6.  Prepare for the worst. Ensure your home and belongings are adequately <br/>        insured, and that your policy is up to date. Keep an itemized list or <br/>        video record of your belongings in a safe place, such as a bank safe <br/>        deposit box.</p><p>    To learn more about how you can safeguard your home and property against <br/>a forest fire read The Home Owners Firesmart Manual available on the Ministry <br/>of Forests Protection Branch Web site at <url normalizedValue="http://www.for.gov.bc.ca/protect/">www.for.gov.bc.ca/protect/</url>. For <br/>questions about home insurance coverage in a forest fire, consult with your <br/>local insurance advisor.</p><p>    BCAA is the province's largest member services organization, working on <br/>behalf of its 730,000 members in B.C. and the Yukon to represent their <br/>interests and satisfy their needs for security and peace of mind in motoring, <br/>travel and at home. In addition to homeowners' and renters' insurance, BCAA <br/>Insurance Agency also offers insurance coverage in the areas of life, extended <br/>health, personal accident, out-of-province medical, They straggled out when the danger passed, Gov. Roy Romer said at a news conference late Wednesday.</p><p>One survivor credited his escape to "strong legs and fast feet.</p><p>"I simply outran the fire up one hill," the man told a Denver television station.</p><p>"It crested the hill and headed down the other side. It doesn't travel downhill as fast as it does uphill."</p><p>Romer called for an investigation to discover why so many lives were lost. Weather forecasters had predicted high wind, but firefighters were left in the field.</p><p>The lightning-sparked fire began Sunday, eight kilometres west of Glenwood Springs.</p><p>The mountain resort of 6,000 people is about 95 kilometres west of Vail and about 290 kilometres west of Denver.</p><p>The fire had been confined to 20 hectares until high wind fanned it out of control Wednesday afternoon. Within five hours, it grew to 800 hectares.</p><p>More than 7,700 firefighters are fighting fires in Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, Wyoming, Montana, Idaho, Utah, Nevada and California.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier "We've had a fairly active spring.</p><p>Four communities in eastern Manitoba were hit hard in the first week of May and about 1,000 people registered as evacuees with the ManitobaRed Cross. They have since returned home.</p><p>Eight homes were lost in the community of St. Theresa Point in the northeast part of the province.</p><p>Cooler temperatures last week provided some relief, and the fires have now been brought under control.</p><p>A restricted fire zone remained in effect for the northern portion of Ontario's eastern fire region. It extends east of Marathon to the Quebec border and north of the French and Mattawa Rivers, including Manitoulin Island.</p><p>Dry conditions, hot sun and wind persist in Ontario, where as of Sunday there were about 23 fires burning.</p><p>On Saturday alone, there were four new fires reported, three in Wawa and one in Algonquin Park.</p><p>A fire reported Thursday in the Northern Ontario town of Chapleau was of particular concern to firefighters, who continued to battle the blaze on the weekend. About 4,500 people live in the town and surrounding area.</p><p>Warm weather is forecast for this week, which could cause the fire to spread.</p><p>Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland have also experienced unusually high forest fire activity this spring.</p><p>Nova Scotia has been hit with two major blazes, one in the Shag Harbour area and the other in Welshtown. Those fires led to the evacuation of about 1,100 people. The Shag Harbour fire destroyed a house, a mobile home and several sheds and hunting camps.</p><p>Last year, 338 fires burned 400 hectares of land in Nova Scotia over the entire forest fire season. Twice as much property has been destroyed so far this year.</p><p>"We had very little snow this winter,'' said John Whidden, communications officer for the Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources.</p><p>Prince Edward Island experienced a small rash of fires early last week, but rain over much of the province brought some relief.</p><p>There was also concern in Newfoundland, where roughly 40 fires were reported last weekend.</p><p>In contrast, British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan have all experienced a quiet spring. Last year was one of the worst forest fire years on record for B.C. and Alberta.</p><p>"What a difference a year makes,'' said Wendy Stewart, B.C. provincial fire information officer.</p><p>"Last year at this time there were 325 fires burning. This year there are 1,000. We've had an extraordinary mix of weather over the last 18 months.''</p><p>Johnston said despite the early start to the year's forest fire season, future activity is difficult to predict because of uncertain weather patterns.</p><p>"Forecasting forest fires is pretty crystal-bally.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Marie. "We have fires burning with no staff on them."</p><p>One hundred campers had to be evacuated Monday from the Big Water Lake Campground near Timmins when a nearby blaze got close enough to pose a serious threat.</p><p>The campground's owner, Marian Tremblay, said most of the campers have returned home, although a few were either staying with friends in the area or at nearby hotels.</p><p>Although the fire wasn't directly headed for the campground, erratic winds could have easily blown it off course, Thomas said.</p><p>David Ramsay, the province's natural resources minister, said he's been keeping a close eye on the fire threat, which often depends more on the whims of Mother Nature than anything else.</p><p>"It's a big fire season, it's always a worry," Ramsay said. "Especially when you've got weather coming through like we've had."</p><p>But Ramsay said he's pleased with the way Ontario's firefighters have kept the fires under control so far -- most notably new technology that allows the province to keep closer track of lightning strikes and deal with fires soon after they begin.</p><p>"I think that's why we've had some good success," he said. Ontario has seen 43 per cent of the country's forest fires so far this year, but lost less than 2 per cent of the area burned across Canada, Ramsay added.</p><p>"We have a very rapid response."</p><p>Some provinces, like British Columbia, won't be able to send any more help because they're dealing with their own fire problems.</p><p>The province has one fire out of control that's taking up a lot of resources, and more blazes are expected to crop up in the coming days, said Radha Fisher, B.C.'s provincial fire information officer. "We're seeing most of the province in high fire danger, and we're starting to see some areas of extreme," Fisher said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Photo: CANADIAN PRESS; A forest fire blazing northwest of the Lac des Iles mine near Thunder Bay has reached a monstrous size enveloping everything in its path. (CP) _ A forest fire has forced the evacuation of residents near this northern Ontario community, 40 kilometres south of North Bay.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>The flames were being whipped by 40 kilometre an hour winds, and smoke from the fire could be seen several kilometres away.</p><p>Resident Betty Ann Storie said at least 50 people were evacuated Tuesday from the Ruth Lake area by the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p> I couldn't get out by road because the roads are all on fire,'' Storie said. I had to go across the lake by boat.''</p><p>Storie said her husband Wayne stayed behind patrolling the lake to make sure everybody had been evacuated.</p><p>Water bombers were in the air Tuesday evening dropping water on the fire.</p><p>The size of the fire wasn't immediately known.</p><p>Tanya Herbert, visiting the area from New York City, was reading outdoors when ashes started dropping on her book.</p><p> There's so much noise and traffic here it is just like the traffic outside my window in Manhattan,'' Herbert said, as the water bombers flew by 60 metres overhead.</p><p> It's a dirty fire,'' said Tom Ball, a ministry of natural resources supervisor. It's hard to attack.''</p><p>Dave Matthews, owner of the nearby Matthews Maple Syrup company, was helping to organize the evacuation Tuesday evening.</p><p> If this fire jumps the road there's not much between here and Trout Creek to stop it,'' Matthews said.</p><p>One man was refusing to leave the area despite provincial police attempts to get him to leave.</p><p>Area residents offered to take evacuees into their homes, and a nearby church was collecting food.</p><p>As well the local firehall was been turned into a temporary shelter since all the firefighters and equipment were battling the forest fire.</p><p>(North Bay Nugget)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Last year was one of the worst forest fire years on record for B.C. and Alberta.</p><p>In eastern Manitoba, four communities were hit hard in the first week of May, but cooler temperatures last week provided some relief, and the fires have now been brought under control.</p><p>At the same time, a restricted fire zone remained in effect for the northern portion of Ontario's eastern fire region.</p><p>It extends east of Marathon to the Quebec border and north of the French and Mattawa Rivers, including Manitoulin Island.</p><p>On Saturday, there were four new fires reported in Ontario, three in Wawa and one in Algonquin Park.</p><p>A fire reported Thursday in the Northern Ontario town of Chapleau was of particular concern to firefighters, who continued to battle the blaze on the weekend. About 4,500 people live in the town and surrounding area.</p><p>Warm weather is forecast for this week, raising fears the fire could spread.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier The Department of Health has the air and road ambulance people on standby."</p><p>So far, Adams-Bower said, no moves have been made to evacuate whole towns or villages in the path of the fires.</p><p>Saskatchewan fire officials said Thursday there are 63 fires burning in the province, 11 are listed as being out of control.</p><p>The village most at risk is La Loche, where a forest fire is burning about eight kilometres from the town.</p><p>There are several small fires burning near the community of 1,600, most were started during a lightning storm earlier this week.</p><p>The Ile-a-la-Crosse blaze, which is burning about 10 kilometres south of the village, has consumed about 7.6 square kilometres of tinder-dry timber. It is the biggest fire in the region.</p><p>Ile-a-la-Crosse is under no immediate threat because it's separated from the fire by an arm of the Churchill River.</p><p>Adams-Bower says her department will team up with the Red Cross to provide evacuation and registration centres if evacuations are ordered.</p><p>If there are members of the public who have to be evacuated and they don't have a family member or a friend's place to go to, then they can go to our reception centre which could be in a school gym or a gym on a reserve if there is one close.</p><p>"They register with the Red Cross and then our staff works to relocate them in a safe place if they have to be there for any length of time and ensure they have the necessities of life, that sort of thing."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
