urn:contentItem:58SM-BP31-DY9S-T1JW-00000-00Thick smoke hampers battle against forest fire in western Labrador2013-06-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisNATIONAL,ATLANTICThick smoke hampers battle against forest fire in western LabradorSmoke hampers battle against Labrador fireThe Canadian Press

WABUSH, N.L. - Thick smoke from a forest fire that continued to rage in western Labrador Saturday hampered efforts to fight the blaze that has forced the evacuation of this small mining community.

Air quality concerns due to the fire burning four kilometres away forced residents to leave their homes Friday night as the town declared a state of emergency.

"For the first two hours this morning we couldn't actually put any crews on the ground or aerial support because there was so much local smoke," said Chuck Porter, a conservation officer with the Department of Natural Resources.

Although four waterbombers were on hand Saturday, poor visibility limited crews to using only one aircraft at a time, said an official with fire and emergency services.

Smoke also prevented the float plane being used from loading with water from Wabush Lake, diverting them instead to the town reservoir. This led to town officials advising residents in the area to boil their water.

"The smoke has settled in the community and that's the reason why, the main reason why, we evacuated at this time," Kevin O'Brien, the minister responsible for the province's fire and emergency services, told The Canadian Press.

"It's a sizeable fire and it's been going for several days."

Approximately 1,400 displaced Wabush residents had registered with the Canadian Red Cross in nearby Labrador City by Saturday morning, most were being accommodated by friends and families in the area.

Of the town's nearly 1,800 residents, 79 chose to disregard the voluntary evacuation order and have stayed in their homes. Emergency personnel are in regular contact with them.

Fire and Emergency Services said the blaze hadn't advanced any closer to Wabush by Saturday afternoon, nor had it grown overnight, but it continued to burn.

"The challenge of the day is the wind," said O'Brien. "We have to reassess on a nearly minute-by-minute basis to make sure you're on the right flank of the fire."

Nearly 30 forest fire specialists were on hand to help fight the blaze.

"We have no rain to help us at all, so it's all by waterbomber and helicopter resources that we're trying to keep the fire in control," said O'Brien.

The fire interrupted Internet and long-distance phone service in the area, including 911 calls, after it broke a fiber-optic cable 20 kilometres outside Labrador City. Residents were provided with alternate phone numbers to report emergencies.

Isabelle Robinson, a spokesperson for Bell Canada, estimated 5,500 customers were affected, mostly in the Labrador City and Wabush area. Service was largely restored by Saturday evening.

The area did not face any imminent threat of losing power said Erin Squires, a spokesperson for Newfoundland and Labrador Hydro.

The fire, which has consumed about 60 square kilometres since last Sunday, also prompted the closure of the Trans-Labrador Highway. A nearly 250-kilometre-long section of road remained closed Saturday between Labrador West and Churchill Falls.

Though Wabush remained under a state of emergency, the provincial government issued a news release Saturday saying the evacuation was precautionary and there was no immediate fire hazard to homes or residents.

The town's displaced residents were said to be coping well. They were being offered food and shelter by the residents and business in Labrador City.

"There's good spirits and we're moving forward," said O'Brien.

"They understand that their safety comes first, they understand as well that we have all the specialists on the ground, so we'll attack this fire until we have it under control and put it out."

Crews continued construction work on a fire break that would afford the town of Wabush an added measure of protection.

Canada Day festivities planned for Monday in Labrador City have been postponed.

urn:contentItem:5C9D-NXG1-JBVR-313G-00000-00Evacuation order lifted as forest fire threat to Saskatchewan community eases2014-05-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisWEATHER,PRAIRIES/BCEvacuation order lifted as forest fire threat to Saskatchewan community easesEvacuation order lifted as fire threat easesThe Canadian Press

STANLEY MISSION, Sask. - About 1,000 people who had to leave a northern Saskatchewan aboriginal community because of a forest fire are returning home.

An evacuation order for Stanley Mission was lifted because rain and backburns by firefighting crews stopped the blaze from advancing toward the community.

Colin King, deputy emergency management commissioner, said people with their own vehicles started going home Monday night.

Evacuees in shelters were being bused back Tuesday, he said. And residents at higher risk - such as elders, pregnant women, young children and anyone with respiratory problems - were to go home Wednesday.

The evacuation was ordered on the weekend because the fire was 10 kilometres from Stanley Mission. It threatened power lines and the only road into the community.

Steve Roberts, the province's executive director of wildfire management, said crews are still working on the fire, but the active part of the fire is further from the access road. Sprinklers that had been placed around Stanley Mission were being removed because the risk is lower, he said.

"Late into the evening and overnight, they also received some rain and cooler temperatures which have further reduced the risk," Roberts said Tuesday.

The fire measures about 7,900 hectares, or 79-square kilometres, but he cautions the figure represents the perimeter of all hotspots and includes lakes, as well as other areas that did not burn.

According to the Ministry of Environment's website, there have been 136 fires so far this year - two less than at this time last year.

Roberts said there is a difference.

"We don't typically get as many large fires this early in the spring. Our fire starts in the spring are man-caused (and) typically are fairly small," he said.

"But because of the delayed winter, our trees have not greened up. They have not been able to absorb moisture and flush out and become lush and green. So what we've seen in this fire behaviour is fire is actually moving through the really, really dry timber. It's not actually burning on the ground - it's moving through the standing timber because it's full of dry needles that aren't green yet.

"So, soon as that's pushed by the wind, it can be very volatile, very dynamic and we don't see that a lot. But if you think about it, it very much looks like a grass fire, but in the standing timber."

- By Jennifer Graham in Regina

urn:contentItem:7W94-SF80-Y9NS-W0JT-00000-00Forest fire in Spain's Canary Islands forces evacuation of 4,000 residents2009-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:53:50ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSForest fire in Spain's Canary Islands forces evacuation of 4,000 residentsCARLOS MORENOCP

LA PALMA, Canary Islands _ A forest fire fanned by high winds has forced the evacuation of about 4,000 residents on the Canary Island of La Palma, the Spanish government said Saturday.

Flames raging on steep hillsides southeast of the island's dormant San Antonio volcano have engulfed several houses and could damage wildlife habitats, environmental worker Narciso Lorenzo said by telephone.

A plume of smoke rose from the island to an estimated height of more than 1,000 metres (3,300 feet). It could be seen clearly from aircraft landing at La Palma airport.

The cause of the fire is unknown. Several days of high temperatures have contributed to dry conditions on the normally verdant La Palma _ one of the least developed and greenest of Spain's Canary Islands, off the West African coast. Pop singer Madonna praised La Palma by its local name in her song ''La Isla Bonita.''

Virtually all the island's firefighting forces, including several aircraft, have been deployed to combat the blaze at three points around the town of Fuencaliente.

Spain sent a Military Emergency Unit from the nearby island of Tenerife, and a battalion was preparing to depart for La Palma from a mainland military base near Seville, the Interior Ministry said in a statement.

The ministry said 52 people were evacuated by boat from an area known for rare Canary pine forests and vineyards.

A smaller fire has been controlled on the nearby island of La Gomera, 30 kilometres (18 miles) southeast of La Palma.

On the mainland, fire crews were combatting four wildfires, from Candamo in northern Asturias to Cortegana in southwestern Huelva, the ministry said.

So far this summer seven people have been killed in wildfires that have consumed an estimated 75,000 hectares (185,325 acres) of forest and farmland in Spain according to the Environment Ministry.

Associated Press writer Harold Heckle in Madrid contributed to this report.

Forest Service said lightning sparked a fire Friday about six kilometres from Creston, B.C. and continued to grow Sunday night.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire, between 25 and 30 hectares, is tricky to fight because it's burning on a steep grade and a 500-kilowatt B.C. Hydro power line is in the way of four helicopters attacking by air, Piazza said.</p><p>Overnight Saturday the fire grew from only two hectares to about 30 hectares that were burning Sunday.</p><p>The terrain is largely rocky with small pockets of trees.</p><p>Some wind late Sunday afternoon was moving the fire south, away from the town, but the U.S. Forest Service is on alert because the blaze is only 300 metres from the B.C.-Idaho border.</p><p>Creston Mayor Don Leben helped set up an emergency response centre in the town hall Sunday to monitor the fire and to meet the needs of firefighters and throngs of tourists.</p><p>This weekend Creston is host to about 7,000 people at a Columbia Brewery bash and a millennium homecoming party, which drew about 500 people.</p><p>Another 1,000 natural gas pipeline workers and their families are in town and Leben expects a crew of 60 firefighters to join 40 who are already there.</p><p>"This town is chock-a-block full right now,'' Leben said.</p><p>The town, usually a quiet home to 5,000, ran out of ice on Saturday so a semi-trailer of it was shipped in.</p><p>"There were no coolers or lawn chairs left in town to buy,'' Leben said. "People are going into drug stores looking for tent pegs.</p><p>"It is a logistical nightmare here. We're just trying to get through this safely.''</p><p>Leben said they have plans for any emergency but there has been no threat of evacuation so far because of the fire.</p><p>"Everything seems to be under control,'' he said.</p><p>The fire came within about two kilometres of Bountiful, a polygamous commune in Lister, B.C., just south of Creston.</p><p>Resident Richard Blackmore said Bountiful wasn't threatened but residents watched with concern.</p><p>"They (firefighters) hit it pretty hard,'' Blackmore said. "They did a good job. We have no complaints.''</p><p>There is a total campfire ban in southeastern B.C.</p><p>Some 12,742 hectares of B.C. forest have burned in the 891 forest fires reported so far this year. People caused 418 of them and lightning strikes caused the rest.</p><p>At this time last year 713 fires had been reported.</p><p>There are about 130 forest fires currently burning, Piazza said, although most are contained and reports of new fires are constantly coming in. Twenty-nine fires were reported Saturday, 24 of them in the parched Boundary-Kootenay region.</p><p>Lightning strikes in the Revelstoke, B.C. area caused some spot fires Sunday. A two-hectare fire is burning in a remote area near Prince George, B.C.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Home » Canada Travel News » Germany Joins Canada And UK In Issuing Urgent Travel Advisory For Portugal Amid Forest Fires And Infrastructure Disruptions: Here’s Everything You Need To Know Published on August 19, 2025 Germany has joined Canada and the UK in issuing an urgent travel advisory for Portugal due to the ongoing wildfire crisis, severe drought conditions, and infrastructure disruptions affecting popular tourist destinations. With severe wildfires sweeping across the mainland and creating heightened hazards for anyone moving through affected areas, travelers are strongly advised to reassess itineraries or to implement enhanced safety measures. Unpredictable fire behavior, extensive road closures, and escalating security risks—especially petty crime—have led officials to release advisories that emphasize the importance of staying updated, obeying local directives, and exercising caution to navigate safely through this unstable and evolving emergency. Germany, along with Canada and the UK, has recently issued a travel advisory for Portugal, urging tourists to reconsider their travel plans or to proceed with caution. The advisory comes in response to ongoing wildfires, severe drought conditions, and widespread infrastructure disruptions across the country. Portugal’s summer wildfire season has intensified, impacting many popular tourist destinations, including Lisbon, Porto, and the Algarve. The travel advisories highlight the immediate risks posed to both residents and visitors, as the wildfires continue to spread across the mainland. Along with fire hazards, travelers must also be mindful of safety concerns such as petty crime, road closures, and delays in transportation services. Germany’s Travel Advisory for Portugal Amid Wildfire Risks and Infrastructure Disruptions Germany’s travel advisory comes as the country grapples with an unprecedented wildfire crisis. The Portuguese government has declared a forest fire alert across the mainland, except for Madeira and the Azores, as fires rage uncontrollably in many regions. The situation has escalated to the point where evacuations are ongoing, and areas like Lisbon, Porto, and the Algarve are particularly vulnerable. Authorities are focusing on containment efforts, but with rapidly changing wind conditions and rising temperatures, the fires remain unpredictable and pose a significant threat to public safety. The German Foreign Office advises tourists to avoid regions directly impacted by the wildfires. Travelers are encouraged to follow fire department updates, stay informed, and refrain from entering forested areas where the fire risk is highest. Road closures and infrastructure disruptions are anticipated, with some areas being cut off due to fire and smoke. This could lead to delays in transport and tourist activities, affecting sightseeing and planned events. Additionally, German tourists are reminded to be cautious about petty crime in busy tourist hotspots. In cities like Lisbon, where the fires have had a ripple effect, pickpocketing incidents are on the rise. Travelers should exercise heightened vigilance, especially in popular districts like Praça do Comércio, Rua Augusta, and Alfama. (CP) - A series of forest fires that forced the evacuation of three communities in southwestern Nova Scotia may have been deliberately set.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Natural Resources Minister Ken MacAskill said Thursday the fires that began Wednesday afternoon "are of a suspicious nature, where seven of them started at the same time.''</p><p>There are no suspects, he said.</p><p>-BODY- The biggest blaze ravaged 810 hectares along Highway 3 in Shelburne County, destroying two homes and severely damaging four others. No one was seriously hurt. About 1,500 people were evacuated from their homes.</p><p>At one point the fire threatened Transportation Minister Clifford Huskilson's home near Shelburne.</p><p>There were other outbreaks in Welshtown, and in Quinan and Lake George, both in Yarmouth County.</p><p>The fire surrounded homes in Shag Harbour, Lower Woods Harbour and Bear Point as frantic residents rushed to their cars to evacuate.</p><p>"It was pretty dicey for awhile,'' said Tina Wickens, warden of Barrington municipality. "But everyone came together and did a great job. I was very impressed.''</p><p>The worst damage was in Shag Harbour, where one house and a mobile home were destroyed. Four others received extensive fire and smoke damage and 11 reported only smoke damage.</p><p>More than a dozen barns, camps and other structures and vehicles were also destroyed or damaged.</p><p>Walter Fanning, provincial manager of forest protection, said by late Thursday afternoon only the Shag Harbour and Welshtown fires were problematic.</p><p>Small fires at Lake George and Quinan, which burned two and three hectares respectively, were extinguished.</p><p>Power substations had to be shut down to protect firefighters in case wires ignited.
